Description: Rim sherd of Chian black-figured Animal pottery chalice; white slip; interior glazed black; part of lotus flower in added white outline with added red centre above two white bands; exterior: at rim, band of dots between brown bands; below, black-figure decoration consisting of cock (lower body missing) to right.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos places this sherd in Stage 4 of the Black Figure Animal Chalice group. Some of the vases in this group have a unique rim pattern. They have filling ornament and the birds featured on the cups are well proportioned and balanced. She also places it in Stage 2 of that group, whose vases were all made by the same artist; the composition is well-balanced and the images are precise. Incision occurs in all the same places.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 331, no. 1596, pl. 204)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 83, no. 44, pl. V)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1316) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
